holidayMaryMotherOfGodDesc: On the first day of the year, this feast celebrates Mary's divine motherhood. She is the mother of Jesus Christ, the Son of God made man. This solemnity is also World Peace Day.
holidayEpiphanyDesc: Epiphany celebrates the manifestation of Jesus to the Magi from the East. These wise men, guided by a star, brought gold, frankincense, and myrrh to the infant Christ. This feast symbolizes God's revelation to all peoples.
holidayPresentationDesc: Forty days after Christmas, this feast commemorates the presentation of Jesus at the Temple in Jerusalem by Mary and Joseph, according to Jewish law. It is also known as Candlemas.
holidaySaintJosephDesc: Feast of Saint Joseph, spouse of the Virgin Mary and foster father of Jesus. He is the patron of workers, fathers, and the Universal Church.
holidayAnnunciationDesc: The Annunciation celebrates the announcement made to Mary by the Archangel Gabriel that she would become the mother of the Son of God. Mary said 'Yes' to God, making the Incarnation possible.
holidayJohnBaptistBirth: Nativity of Saint John the Baptist
holidayJohnBaptistBirthDesc: This feast celebrates the birth of John the Baptist, the forerunner of Christ. He prepared the way of the Lord and baptized Jesus in the Jordan River.
holidayPeterPaulDesc: A solemnity celebrating the two pillars of the Church: Peter, the leader of the apostles to whom Jesus entrusted the keys of the Kingdom, and Paul, the apostle to the nations who evangelized the pagan world.
holidayTransfigurationDesc: The Transfiguration commemorates the moment when Jesus, on Mount Tabor, revealed his divine glory to Peter, James, and John. His face shone like the sun.
holidayAssumptionDesc: The Assumption celebrates the Virgin Mary's ascent to heaven with her soul and body at the end of her earthly life. She was the first of the redeemed to enter heavenly glory.
holidayMaryBirth: Nativity of the Blessed Virgin Mary
holidayMaryBirthDesc: This feast celebrates the birth of Mary, who would become the mother of Jesus. She was born without original sin, prepared by God to be the mother of the Savior.
holidayHolyCrossDesc: This feast exalts the Holy Cross, the instrument of our salvation. It commemorates the discovery of the True Cross by Saint Helena and Christ's victory over death.
holidayAllSaintsDesc: All Saints is the feast of all saints, known and unknown, who are in paradise. It reminds us that we are all called to holiness and eternal life with God.
holidayAllSoulsDesc: The day after All Saints, the Church prays for all the faithful departed who are in purgatory, so that they may be purified and enter the joy of Heaven.
holidayImmaculateConceptionDesc: This solemnity celebrates Mary's conception without original sin. From the first moment of her existence, Mary was preserved from sin to become the mother of the Savior.
holidayChristmasDesc: Christmas celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ in Bethlehem. The Son of God became man to save us. It is the feast of God's love coming to dwell among us.
holidaySaintStephenDesc: Feast of the first Christian martyr. Stephen, a deacon filled with the Holy Spirit, was stoned for his faith in Jesus Christ. He forgave his executioners as Christ did on the cross.
holidaySaintJohnDesc: Feast of the Apostle John, the disciple whom Jesus loved. He is the author of the fourth Gospel, three epistles, and Revelation. He is the only apostle to die of old age.
holidayHolyInnocentsDesc: This feast commemorates the children of Bethlehem massacred by order of King Herod, who was trying to kill the infant Jesus. They are considered the first martyrs.
holidayAshWednesdayDesc: The beginning of Lent, a 40-day period of preparation for Easter. The ashes, placed on the forehead, remind us of our mortality and invite us to conversion.
holidayPalmSundayDesc: This Sunday opens Holy Week and commemorates Jesus' triumphal entry into Jerusalem. The people acclaimed him with palm branches, crying 'Hosanna!'
holidayHolyThursdayDesc: Holy Thursday commemorates Jesus' last supper with his apostles, during which he instituted the Eucharist and the priesthood. He also washed his disciples' feet.
holidayGoodFridayDesc: Good Friday is the day of Jesus' crucifixion and death on the cross. It is a day of fasting and prayer when the Church venerates the Cross of the Savior.
holidayHolySaturdayDesc: A day of silence and waiting between Christ's death and resurrection. The Church keeps vigil at the tomb. The Easter Vigil, at night, celebrates the Resurrection.
holidayEasterDesc: Easter is the greatest Christian feast. It celebrates the resurrection of Jesus Christ, victorious over death. It is the foundation of our faith and the hope of eternal life.
holidayEasterMondayDesc: Easter Monday extends the Easter joy. The Gospel tells of the disciples of Emmaus meeting the risen Jesus, whom they recognized in the breaking of bread.
holidayDivineMercyDesc: Instituted by Saint John Paul II, this Sunday celebrates God's infinite mercy. Jesus entrusted this message to Saint Faustina: 'Jesus, I trust in You.'
holidayAscensionDesc: The Ascension celebrates Jesus' ascent to Heaven, forty days after Easter. The risen Christ joins his Father and opens the way to eternal life for us.
holidayPentecostDesc: Pentecost celebrates the descent of the Holy Spirit upon the apostles, fifty days after Easter. It is the birth of the Church. The apostles received the power to proclaim the Gospel.
holidayPentecostMondayDesc: Pentecost Monday extends the feast of Pentecost and celebrates the gifts of the Holy Spirit poured out on the Church and on every baptized person.
holidayTrinityDesc: The feast of the Holy Trinity celebrates the central mystery of the Christian faith: one God in three equal and distinct persons - the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit.
holidayCorpusChristiDesc: Corpus Christi celebrates the real presence of Jesus Christ in the Eucharist. Solemn processions carry the consecrated host to manifest faith in this mystery of love.
holidaySacredHeartDesc: This feast celebrates Christ's infinite love for humanity, symbolized by his Heart. Jesus revealed his Heart to Saint Margaret Mary: 'Behold this Heart which has loved men so much.'
holidayChristKingDesc: The last feast of the liturgical year, it proclaims the universal kingship of Christ over all creation. His reign is one of love, justice, and peace.
holidayAdventDesc: The beginning of the liturgical year and Advent season, a four-week period of preparation for Christmas. The Church awaits the coming of the Savior with hope.
